unnormalised: ## The Accidental IT Guy: My Journey from Chaiwala to Cloud Architect
normalised: ## The Accidental I-T Guy: My Journey from Chaiwala to Cloud Architect

unnormalised: It all started innocently enough, with a broken computer at my father’s small grocery shop in Lucknow. I was, at the time, mostly occupied with delivering chai and helping with the accounts. This old desktop, running Win XP, was crucial for managing inventory, and when it crashed – blue screen and all – panic ensued. My father, bless his heart, threatened to replace it with an abacus. That's when I stepped in.
normalised: It all started innocently enough, with a broken computer at my father’s small grocery shop in Lucknow. I was, at the time, mostly occupied with delivering chai and helping with the accounts. This old desktop, running Windows X-P, was crucial for managing inventory, and when it crashed – blue screen and all – panic ensued. My father, bless his heart, threatened to replace it with an abacus. That's when I stepped in.

unnormalised: I remember spending hours at the local cyber cafe, browsing forums and watching YouTube tutorials. Dial-up internet was painfully slow, but I was determined. I learned about boot sectors, corrupted files, and the magic of reinstalling an OS. After what felt like an eternity, I managed to bring that old machine back to life. The sheer joy on my father’s face was enough to hook me. The seed, you see, was planted.
normalised: I remember spending hours at the local cyber cafe, browsing forums and watching YouTube tutorials. Dial-up internet was painfully slow, but I was determined. I learned about boot sectors, corrupted files, and the magic of reinstalling an O-S. After what felt like an eternity, I managed to bring that old machine back to life. The sheer joy on my father’s face was enough to hook me. The seed, you see, was planted.

unnormalised: From there, my curiosity only grew. I started tinkering with other devices, fixing broken phones, and even building simple websites for friends using HTML. Remember GeoCities? Ah, the memories! My marks in school weren’t stellar – a modest 60% in my 10th boards – but I excelled at anything computer-related. My family and friends started calling me "The Computer Doctor." It felt... good.
normalised: From there, my curiosity only grew. I started tinkering with other devices, fixing broken phones, and even building simple websites for friends using H-T-M-L. Remember GeoCities? Ah, the memories! My marks in school weren’t stellar – a modest sixty percent in my tenth boards – but I excelled at anything computer-related. My family and friends started calling me "The Computer Doctor." It felt... good.

unnormalised: The turning point came when a local IT company, "TechSolutions Ltd.", advertised for a junior technician. I barely met the qualifications – a high school diploma and a burning passion – but I applied anyway. To my surprise, I got an interview. Mr. Sharma, the owner, saw something in me, perhaps the same desperate eagerness that had driven me to fix that first computer. He hired me, paying Rs. 5000 a month. A pittance, but it was a foot in the door.
normalised: The turning point came when a local I-T company, "TechSolutions Limited", advertised for a junior technician. I barely met the qualifications – a high school diploma and a burning passion – but I applied anyway. To my surprise, I got an interview. Mister Sharma, the owner, saw something in me, perhaps the same desperate eagerness that had driven me to fix that first computer. He hired me, paying rupees five thousand a month. A pittance, but it was a foot in the door.

unnormalised: My first job involved mostly cleaning computers, running errands, and answering phones. The work was monotonous, but I devoured any knowledge I could get my hands on. I learned about network administration, server maintenance, and the basics of cybersecurity. I even managed to get certified in CompTIA A+ and Network+ during my first year, studying after work until 2:00 AM.
normalised: My first job involved mostly cleaning computers, running errands, and answering phones. The work was monotonous, but I devoured any knowledge I could get my hands on. I learned about network administration, server maintenance, and the basics of cybersecurity. I even managed to get certified in Comp-T-I-A A-plus and Network-plus during my first year, studying after work until two zero zero A-M.

unnormalised: Then came the cloud revolution. TechSolutions, recognizing the shift in the industry, started offering cloud services. I was assigned to the project, again with minimal experience, but boundless enthusiasm. I spent countless hours learning about AWS, Azure, and GCP, devouring documentation and experimenting with virtual machines. The learning curve was steep, steeper than the hills of Mussoorie, but I persevered.

I spent countless hours learning about A-W-S, Azure, and G-C-P, devouring documentation and experimenting with virtual machines. The learning curve was steep, steeper than the hills of Mussoorie, but I persevered.

unnormalised: Today, several years later, I am proud to call myself a Cloud Architect at a multinational corporation. I manage complex cloud infrastructure, design scalable solutions, and even mentor junior engineers. The journey from a chaiwala’s son tinkering with an old Win XP machine to a cloud architect has been long and arduous. It's been filled with late nights, frustrating errors, and moments of self-doubt. It began 15 yrs ago in 2009.

I manage complex cloud infrastructure, design scalable solutions, and even mentor junior engineers. The journey from a chaiwala’s son tinkering with an old Windows X-P machine to a cloud architect has been long and arduous. It's been filled with late nights, frustrating errors, and moments of self-doubt. It began fifteen years ago in two thousand and nine.

unnormalised: But, looking back, I wouldn't trade it for anything. The broken computer, the slow internet, the measly salary – they all shaped me into the IT professional I am today. And it all started with a single, simple act: fixing my father’s computer. Sometimes, the most extraordinary journeys begin in the most ordinary of places. Remember that kid at cyber cafe, he will be somewhere doing something big.
